Tucson sits down on his bed, in dragon mode and rubs his head against Talon=
's shoulder.  This further loosens up dull scale like film which comes off =
like silver translucent material, similar to what a snake sheds.  Beneath i=
t, brilliant shimmering scales emerge.  It was like he was slowly evolving =
beneath an old skin.  And as serpents do, his tail seems to grow a tiny bit=
 longer with the shedding of his old skin.  Yet this was only happening in =
his beast mode.  

" Hmm..  Talon, could you scratch behind my neck for me?=
  It's the one place I can't reach.  I've never encountered shedding, and t=
his must be what happened to the old dragon from time to time."

Uproar loo=
ks to the shed material curiously and paws at it.  He finds it hard like me=
tal.

" Woah, it got really hard.  Like armor almost.  Neat.  This must hap=
pen ta reptiles all the time.  I've even heard of spiders shedding skins if=
 you can believe that.  Ughhh..  I bet Tarantulus does that too, when he's =
in spider mode. Hey speak'n of natural processes, dragons are thought ta br=
eathe fire, but you don't seem ta do that huh?"

Tucson shakes his head.

"=
 No, but I do recall being able to produce some electrical particles using =
the same principle .  And when I roar, it mimics the sound of thunder.  I s=
uspect the old dragon was some sort of elemental master.  He breathes light=
ning and roars out thunder through his vocal chords.  I'm beginning to thin=
k he may have past that down to me."

Uproar chuckles.

" That means when y=
ou and Talon have a family, your offspring is gonna inherit that ability.  =
Ya never know, your first kid might end up being a dragon, or ya might get =
lucky and have one of each.  But if it does take after dear old dad, better=
 make sure it's not a fire breather."

Tucson chuckles and rubs his paw on =
Uproars head, messing up his fur in a playful manner.

" We'll see, don't c=
ount the dragons before they hatch."

Uproar continues to laugh.

" No, ser=
iously, dragons are known ta have more than just one offspring.  They're li=
ke gators and crocs, they tend to have a clutch of eggs that hatch into hat=
chlings.   Reptiles and birds normally produce eggs that hatch when they've=
 fully developed.  The only exception is, that some snake species actually =
bare live young.  Now that could happen too, but for the most part, dragons=
 lay eggs and so do birds.  Soooo, you guys might just produce a small clut=
ch of eggs that need ta be incubated over a course of time.  I dunno, its j=
ust some intel I read on birds and reptiles."

Tucson nods.

" It's alright=
, I've read that too at one point.  You're correct, it could happen that wa=
y.  Which makes me curious as to other organic properties I seem to be expe=
riencing..  Like hunger...  I admit, I snapped up a fish from a near by wat=
er source and I consumed it in beast mode.  And the other mammals for some =
odd reason sparked my appetite.  But I didn't have the spark to hunt them. =
 I merely got a meal from the water instead. "

Uproar nods.

" Confession,=
 I took down a wild pig and I ate it... In beast mode of course.  And it ta=
sted really good too.  I bet Stanton would know what's happening to us, rig=
ht Stanton?"

Local artist who specializes in illustration, using tradition=
al and digital media.  

I also specialize in hand made crafts.  Great for =
any occasion!  

Need a great gift idea that is original?  No problem!  Ema=
il me at this address and we will talk.

s bed
> 
> --- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Super Cyclonus <supercyclonus@...=

> >
> > As TUCSON and UPROAR get up on the beds BUMP activated the=
 control
> > panel next to each one and red beams of light began strobing a=
cross
> > both of them, scanning them intensly.
> > 
> > "Hmm." SANTON said=
 from the readout screen. "This is similar to the
> > one Taratulus had dev=
eloped, but it has changed somewhat."
> > 
> > "What?" BUMP said. "How? Why=
?"
> > 
> > SANTON scratched his head for a moment as he thought, "It looks=
 like
> > it is the same thing that happened to human strains of flu and ot=
her
> > viruses. As they interact with the enviornment around them they cha=
nge
> > and modify."
> > 
> > There was a pause from BUMP, "Does that mean =
that this strain is more
> > resistant to the cure?"
> > 
> > "I don't know=
." SANTON said. He glanced up at LEGACY who had just
> > finished entering =
his codes. "What do you think?"
> > 
> > LEGACY stepped away from his panel=
 as the program executed. "Unknown,
> > this strain appears to be essential=
ly the same." He said quietly. "I
> > have replicated the antiviral injecti=
on just as prescribed and have
> > added other additional medicines." He sa=
id coldly. "I would surmise
> > that it would be at least partially effecti=
ve. However to what degree
> > is difficult to quantify."
> > 
> > There wa=
s a nod from BUMP, "So it may cure them . . . "
> > 
> > ". . . or it may d=
o nothing at all." SANTON said as he realized the
> > import of their words=
.
> > 
> > There was a hissing sound as injection guns rose from the beds o=
f
> > TUSCON and UPROAR. Efficiently they fed both of them the 'cure'.
> > =

> > LEGACY, BUMP and SANTON looked at the vital signs readout and waited
>=
 > to see what the response would be.
> > 
> > (TAG)
> > 
> > - Preston
